PIQUE Cloud quality model 7PK.description: Model description, replace with a description of your model

Confidentiality.description: Information is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized individuals, entities, or processes.

Integrity.description: Data or processes cannot be modified in an unauthorized way.

Availability.description: Data and processes should be available at all times when deemed necessary.

Authenticity.description: Identity of individuals, entities, or processes is verified correctly.

Authorization.description: individuals, entities, or processes only have access to data and processes they should.

Non-repudiation.description: Individuals, entities, or processes may not deny any actions they performed.

Variant CWE-5.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Data Transmission Without Encryption
Variant CWE-5.description: Information sent over a network can be compromised while in transit. An attacker may be able to read or modify the contents if the data are sent in plaintext or are weakly encrypted.

Variant CWE-6.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Insufficient Session-ID Length
Variant CWE-6.description: The J2EE application is configured to use an insufficient session ID length.

Variant CWE-7.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
Variant CWE-7.description: The default error page of a web application should not display sensitive information about the product.

Variant CWE-8.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Entity Bean Declared Remote
Variant CWE-8.description: When an application exposes a remote interface for an entity bean, it might also expose methods that get or set the bean's data. These methods could be leveraged to read sensitive information, or to change data in ways that violate the application's expectations, potentially leading to other vulnerabilities.

Variant CWE-9.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Weak Access Permissions for EJB Methods
Variant CWE-9.description: If elevated access rights are assigned to EJB methods, then an attacker can take advantage of the permissions to exploit the product.

Variant CWE-11.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Creating Debug Binary
Variant CWE-11.description: Debugging messages help attackers learn about the system and plan a form of attack.

Variant CWE-12.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
Variant CWE-12.description: An ASP .NET application must enable custom error pages in order to prevent attackers from mining information from the framework's built-in responses.

Variant CWE-13.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Password in Configuration File
Variant CWE-13.description: Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource making them an easy target for attackers.

Variant CWE-14.name: Compiler Removal of Code to Clear Buffers
Variant CWE-14.description: Sensitive memory is cleared according to the source code, but compiler optimizations leave the memory untouched when it is not read from again, aka dead store removal.

Class CWE-20.name: Improper Input Validation
Class CWE-20.description: The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

Class CWE-77.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection')
Class CWE-77.description: The product constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.

Base CWE-79.name: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
Base CWE-79.description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

Base CWE-89.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection')
Base CWE-89.description: The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

Class CWE-99.name: Improper Control of Resource Identifiers ('Resource Injection')
Class CWE-99.description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the input before it is used as an identifier for a resource that may be outside the intended sphere of control.

Base CWE-242.name: Use of Inherently Dangerous Function
Base CWE-242.description: The product calls a function that can never be guaranteed to work safely.

Variant CWE-243.name: Creation of chroot Jail Without Changing Working Directory
Variant CWE-243.description: The product uses the chroot() system call to create a jail, but does not change the working directory afterward. This does not prevent access to files outside of the jail.

Variant CWE-244.name: Improper Clearing of Heap Memory Before Release ('Heap Inspection')
Variant CWE-244.description: Using realloc() to resize buffers that store sensitive information can leave the sensitive information exposed to attack, because it is not removed from memory.

Variant CWE-245.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Management of Connections
Variant CWE-245.description: The J2EE application directly manages connections, instead of using the container's connection management facilities.

Variant CWE-246.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Sockets
Variant CWE-246.description: The J2EE application directly uses sockets instead of using framework method calls.

Base CWE-248.name: Uncaught Exception
Base CWE-248.description: An exception is thrown from a function, but it is not caught.

Base CWE-250.name: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
Base CWE-250.description: The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

Base CWE-252.name: Unchecked Return Value
Base CWE-252.description: The product does not check the return value from a method or function, which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions.

Base CWE-256.name: Plaintext Storage of a Password
Base CWE-256.description: Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise.

Variant CWE-258.name: Empty Password in Configuration File
Variant CWE-258.description: Using an empty string as a password is insecure.

Variant CWE-259.name: Use of Hard-coded Password
Variant CWE-259.description: The product contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.

Base CWE-260.name: Password in Configuration File
Base CWE-260.description: The product stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password.

Base CWE-261.name: Weak Encoding for Password
Base CWE-261.description: Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password.

Base CWE-272.name: Least Privilege Violation
Base CWE-272.description: The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

Pillar CWE-284.name: Improper Access Control
Pillar CWE-284.description: The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

Class CWE-285.name: Improper Authorization
Class CWE-285.description: The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

Class CWE-330.name: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
Class CWE-330.description: The product uses insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

Base CWE-359.name: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
Base CWE-359.description: The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

Base CWE-364.name: Signal Handler Race Condition
Base CWE-364.description: The product uses a signal handler that introduces a race condition.

Base CWE-367.name: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition
Base CWE-367.description: The product checks the state of a resource before using that resource, but the resource's state can change between the check and the use in a way that invalidates the results of the check. This can cause the product to perform invalid actions when the resource is in an unexpected state.

Class CWE-377.name: Insecure Temporary File
Class CWE-377.description: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

Variant CWE-382.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Use of System.exit()
Variant CWE-382.description: A J2EE application uses System.exit(), which also shuts down its container.

Variant CWE-383.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Threads
Variant CWE-383.description: Thread management in a Web application is forbidden in some circumstances and is always highly error prone.

Compound CWE-384.name: Session Fixation
Compound CWE-384.description: Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

Base CWE-391.name: Unchecked Error Condition
Base CWE-391.description: [PLANNED FOR DEPRECATION. SEE MAINTENANCE NOTES AND CONSIDER CWE-252, CWE-248, OR CWE-1069.] Ignoring exceptions and other error conditions may allow an attacker to induce unexpected behavior unnoticed.

Base CWE-395.name: Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference
Base CWE-395.description: Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer.

Base CWE-396.name: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception
Base CWE-396.description: Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities.

Base CWE-397.name: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
Base CWE-397.description: Throwing overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities.

Variant CWE-401.name: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime
Variant CWE-401.description: The product does not sufficiently track and release allocated memory after it has been used, which slowly consumes remaining memory.

Class CWE-404.name: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release
Class CWE-404.description: The product does not release or incorrectly releases a resource before it is made available for re-use.

Base CWE-412.name: Unrestricted Externally Accessible Lock
Base CWE-412.description: The product properly checks for the existence of a lock, but the lock can be externally controlled or influenced by an actor that is outside of the intended sphere of control.

Variant CWE-415.name: Double Free
Variant CWE-415.description: The product calls free() twice on the same memory address, potentially leading to modification of unexpected memory locations.

Variant CWE-416.name: Use After Free
Variant CWE-416.description: Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

Variant CWE-457.name: Use of Uninitialized Variable
Variant CWE-457.description: The code uses a variable that has not been initialized, leading to unpredictable or unintended results.

Base CWE-474.name: Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations
Base CWE-474.description: The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions.

Base CWE-475.name: Undefined Behavior for Input to API
Base CWE-475.description: The behavior of this function is undefined unless its control parameter is set to a specific value.

Base CWE-476.name: NULL Pointer Dereference
Base CWE-476.description: A NULL pointer dereference occurs when the application dereferences a pointer that it expects to be valid, but is NULL, typically causing a crash or exit.

Base CWE-477.name: Use of Obsolete Function
Base CWE-477.description: The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

Variant CWE-486.name: Comparison of Classes by Name
Variant CWE-486.description: The product compares classes by name, which can cause it to use the wrong class when multiple classes can have the same name.

Base CWE-488.name: Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session
Base CWE-488.description: The product does not sufficiently enforce boundaries between the states of different sessions, causing data to be provided to, or used by, the wrong session.

Base CWE-489.name: Active Debug Code
Base CWE-489.description: The product is deployed to unauthorized actors with debugging code still enabled or active, which can create unintended entry points or expose sensitive information.

Variant CWE-491.name: Public cloneable() Method Without Final ('Object Hijack')
Variant CWE-491.description: A class has a cloneable() method that is not declared final, which allows an object to be created without calling the constructor. This can cause the object to be in an unexpected state.

Variant CWE-492.name: Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data
Variant CWE-492.description: Inner classes are translated into classes that are accessible at package scope and may expose code that the programmer intended to keep private to attackers.

Variant CWE-493.name: Critical Public Variable Without Final Modifier
Variant CWE-493.description: The product has a critical public variable that is not final, which allows the variable to be modified to contain unexpected values.

Variant CWE-495.name: Private Data Structure Returned From A Public Method
Variant CWE-495.description: The product has a method that is declared public, but returns a reference to a private data structure, which could then be modified in unexpected ways.

Variant CWE-496.name: Public Data Assigned to Private Array-Typed Field
Variant CWE-496.description: Assigning public data to a private array is equivalent to giving public access to the array.

Base CWE-497.name: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
Base CWE-497.description: The product does not properly prevent sensitive system-level information from being accessed by unauthorized actors who do not have the same level of access to the underlying system as the product does.

Base CWE-501.name: Trust Boundary Violation
Base CWE-501.description: The product mixes trusted and untrusted data in the same data structure or structured message.

Variant CWE-558.name: Use of getlogin() in Multithreaded Application
Variant CWE-558.description: The product uses the getlogin() function in a multithreaded context, potentially causing it to return incorrect values.

Base CWE-798.name: Use of Hard-coded Credentials
Base CWE-798.description: The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

CWE-5.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Data Transmission Without Encryption
CWE-5.description: Information sent over a network can be compromised while in transit. An attacker may be able to read or modify the contents if the data are sent in plaintext or are weakly encrypted.

CWE-6.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Insufficient Session-ID Length
CWE-6.description: The J2EE application is configured to use an insufficient session ID length.

CWE-7.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
CWE-7.description: The default error page of a web application should not display sensitive information about the product.

CWE-8.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Entity Bean Declared Remote
CWE-8.description: When an application exposes a remote interface for an entity bean, it might also expose methods that get or set the bean's data. These methods could be leveraged to read sensitive information, or to change data in ways that violate the application's expectations, potentially leading to other vulnerabilities.

CWE-9.name: J2EE Misconfiguration: Weak Access Permissions for EJB Methods
CWE-9.description: If elevated access rights are assigned to EJB methods, then an attacker can take advantage of the permissions to exploit the product.

CWE-11.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Creating Debug Binary
CWE-11.description: Debugging messages help attackers learn about the system and plan a form of attack.

CWE-12.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
CWE-12.description: An ASP .NET application must enable custom error pages in order to prevent attackers from mining information from the framework's built-in responses.

CWE-13.name: ASP.NET Misconfiguration: Password in Configuration File
CWE-13.description: Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource making them an easy target for attackers.

CWE-14.name: Compiler Removal of Code to Clear Buffers
CWE-14.description: Sensitive memory is cleared according to the source code, but compiler optimizations leave the memory untouched when it is not read from again, aka dead store removal.

CWE-15.name: External Control of System or Configuration Setting
CWE-15.description: One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user.

CWE-20.name: Improper Input Validation
CWE-20.description: The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

CWE-73.name: External Control of File Name or Path
CWE-73.description: The product allows user input to control or influence paths or file names that are used in filesystem operations.

CWE-77.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection')
CWE-77.description: The product constructs all or part of a command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended command when it is sent to a downstream component.

CWE-79.name: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
CWE-79.description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

CWE-89.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection')
CWE-89.description: The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

CWE-99.name: Improper Control of Resource Identifiers ('Resource Injection')
CWE-99.description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not restrict or incorrectly restricts the input before it is used as an identifier for a resource that may be outside the intended sphere of control.

CWE-102.name: Struts: Duplicate Validation Forms
CWE-102.description: The product uses multiple validation forms with the same name, which might cause the Struts Validator to validate a form that the programmer does not expect.

CWE-103.name: Struts: Incomplete validate() Method Definition
CWE-103.description: The product has a validator form that either does not define a validate() method, or defines a validate() method but does not call super.validate().

CWE-104.name: Struts: Form Bean Does Not Extend Validation Class
CWE-104.description: If a form bean does not extend an ActionForm subclass of the Validator framework, it can expose the application to other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

CWE-105.name: Struts: Form Field Without Validator
CWE-105.description: The product has a form field that is not validated by a corresponding validation form, which can introduce other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

CWE-106.name: Struts: Plug-in Framework not in Use
CWE-106.description: When an application does not use an input validation framework such as the Struts Validator, there is a greater risk of introducing weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

CWE-107.name: Struts: Unused Validation Form
CWE-107.description: An unused validation form indicates that validation logic is not up-to-date.

CWE-108.name: Struts: Unvalidated Action Form
CWE-108.description: Every Action Form must have a corresponding validation form.

CWE-109.name: Struts: Validator Turned Off
CWE-109.description: Automatic filtering via a Struts bean has been turned off, which disables the Struts Validator and custom validation logic. This exposes the application to other weaknesses related to insufficient input validation.

CWE-110.name: Struts: Validator Without Form Field
CWE-110.description: Validation fields that do not appear in forms they are associated with indicate that the validation logic is out of date.

CWE-111.name: Direct Use of Unsafe JNI
CWE-111.description: When a Java application uses the Java Native Interface (JNI) to call code written in another programming language, it can expose the application to weaknesses in that code, even if those weaknesses cannot occur in Java.

CWE-112.name: Missing XML Validation
CWE-112.description: The product accepts XML from an untrusted source but does not validate the XML against the proper schema.

CWE-113.name: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences in HTTP Headers ('HTTP Request/Response Splitting')
CWE-113.description: The product receives data from an HTTP agent/component (e.g., web server, proxy, browser, etc.), but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes CR and LF characters before the data is included in outgoing HTTP headers.

CWE-114.name: Process Control
CWE-114.description: Executing commands or loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands (and payloads) on behalf of an attacker.

CWE-117.name: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs
CWE-117.description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes output that is written to logs.

CWE-119.name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer
CWE-119.description: The product performs operations on a memory buffer, but it can read from or write to a memory location that is outside of the intended boundary of the buffer.

CWE-120.name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')
CWE-120.description: The product copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer, leading to a buffer overflow.

CWE-134.name: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String
CWE-134.description: The product uses a function that accepts a format string as an argument, but the format string originates from an external source.

CWE-170.name: Improper Null Termination
CWE-170.description: The product does not terminate or incorrectly terminates a string or array with a null character or equivalent terminator.

CWE-190.name: Integer Overflow or Wraparound
CWE-190.description: The product performs a calculation that can produce an integer overflow or wraparound, when the logic assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than the original value. This can introduce other weaknesses when the calculation is used for resource management or execution control.

CWE-242.name: Use of Inherently Dangerous Function
CWE-242.description: The product calls a function that can never be guaranteed to work safely.

CWE-243.name: Creation of chroot Jail Without Changing Working Directory
CWE-243.description: The product uses the chroot() system call to create a jail, but does not change the working directory afterward. This does not prevent access to files outside of the jail.

CWE-244.name: Improper Clearing of Heap Memory Before Release ('Heap Inspection')
CWE-244.description: Using realloc() to resize buffers that store sensitive information can leave the sensitive information exposed to attack, because it is not removed from memory.

CWE-245.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Management of Connections
CWE-245.description: The J2EE application directly manages connections, instead of using the container's connection management facilities.

CWE-246.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Sockets
CWE-246.description: The J2EE application directly uses sockets instead of using framework method calls.

CWE-248.name: Uncaught Exception
CWE-248.description: An exception is thrown from a function, but it is not caught.

CWE-250.name: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
CWE-250.description: The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

CWE-252.name: Unchecked Return Value
CWE-252.description: The product does not check the return value from a method or function, which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions.

CWE-256.name: Plaintext Storage of a Password
CWE-256.description: Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise.

CWE-258.name: Empty Password in Configuration File
CWE-258.description: Using an empty string as a password is insecure.

CWE-259.name: Use of Hard-coded Password
CWE-259.description: The product contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.

CWE-260.name: Password in Configuration File
CWE-260.description: The product stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password.

CWE-261.name: Weak Encoding for Password
CWE-261.description: Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password.

CWE-272.name: Least Privilege Violation
CWE-272.description: The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

CWE-284.name: Improper Access Control
CWE-284.description: The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

CWE-285.name: Improper Authorization
CWE-285.description: The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

CWE-330.name: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
CWE-330.description: The product uses insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

CWE-359.name: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
CWE-359.description: The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

CWE-364.name: Signal Handler Race Condition
CWE-364.description: The product uses a signal handler that introduces a race condition.

CWE-367.name: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition
CWE-367.description: The product checks the state of a resource before using that resource, but the resource's state can change between the check and the use in a way that invalidates the results of the check. This can cause the product to perform invalid actions when the resource is in an unexpected state.

CWE-377.name: Insecure Temporary File
CWE-377.description: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

CWE-382.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Use of System.exit()
CWE-382.description: A J2EE application uses System.exit(), which also shuts down its container.

CWE-383.name: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Threads
CWE-383.description: Thread management in a Web application is forbidden in some circumstances and is always highly error prone.

CWE-384.name: Session Fixation
CWE-384.description: Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

CWE-391.name: Unchecked Error Condition
CWE-391.description: [PLANNED FOR DEPRECATION. SEE MAINTENANCE NOTES AND CONSIDER CWE-252, CWE-248, OR CWE-1069.] Ignoring exceptions and other error conditions may allow an attacker to induce unexpected behavior unnoticed.

CWE-395.name: Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference
CWE-395.description: Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer.

CWE-396.name: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception
CWE-396.description: Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities.

CWE-397.name: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
CWE-397.description: Throwing overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities.

CWE-401.name: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime
CWE-401.description: The product does not sufficiently track and release allocated memory after it has been used, which slowly consumes remaining memory.

CWE-404.name: Improper Resource Shutdown or Release
CWE-404.description: The product does not release or incorrectly releases a resource before it is made available for re-use.

CWE-412.name: Unrestricted Externally Accessible Lock
CWE-412.description: The product properly checks for the existence of a lock, but the lock can be externally controlled or influenced by an actor that is outside of the intended sphere of control.

CWE-415.name: Double Free
CWE-415.description: The product calls free() twice on the same memory address, potentially leading to modification of unexpected memory locations.

CWE-416.name: Use After Free
CWE-416.description: Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

CWE-457.name: Use of Uninitialized Variable
CWE-457.description: The code uses a variable that has not been initialized, leading to unpredictable or unintended results.

CWE-466.name: Return of Pointer Value Outside of Expected Range
CWE-466.description: A function can return a pointer to memory that is outside of the buffer that the pointer is expected to reference.

CWE-470.name: Use of Externally-Controlled Input to Select Classes or Code ('Unsafe Reflection')
CWE-470.description: The product uses external input with reflection to select which classes or code to use, but it does not sufficiently prevent the input from selecting improper classes or code.

CWE-474.name: Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations
CWE-474.description: The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions.

CWE-475.name: Undefined Behavior for Input to API
CWE-475.description: The behavior of this function is undefined unless its control parameter is set to a specific value.

CWE-476.name: NULL Pointer Dereference
CWE-476.description: A NULL pointer dereference occurs when the application dereferences a pointer that it expects to be valid, but is NULL, typically causing a crash or exit.

CWE-477.name: Use of Obsolete Function
CWE-477.description: The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

CWE-486.name: Comparison of Classes by Name
CWE-486.description: The product compares classes by name, which can cause it to use the wrong class when multiple classes can have the same name.

CWE-488.name: Exposure of Data Element to Wrong Session
CWE-488.description: The product does not sufficiently enforce boundaries between the states of different sessions, causing data to be provided to, or used by, the wrong session.

CWE-489.name: Active Debug Code
CWE-489.description: The product is deployed to unauthorized actors with debugging code still enabled or active, which can create unintended entry points or expose sensitive information.

CWE-491.name: Public cloneable() Method Without Final ('Object Hijack')
CWE-491.description: A class has a cloneable() method that is not declared final, which allows an object to be created without calling the constructor. This can cause the object to be in an unexpected state.

CWE-492.name: Use of Inner Class Containing Sensitive Data
CWE-492.description: Inner classes are translated into classes that are accessible at package scope and may expose code that the programmer intended to keep private to attackers.

CWE-493.name: Critical Public Variable Without Final Modifier
CWE-493.description: The product has a critical public variable that is not final, which allows the variable to be modified to contain unexpected values.

CWE-495.name: Private Data Structure Returned From A Public Method
CWE-495.description: The product has a method that is declared public, but returns a reference to a private data structure, which could then be modified in unexpected ways.

CWE-496.name: Public Data Assigned to Private Array-Typed Field
CWE-496.description: Assigning public data to a private array is equivalent to giving public access to the array.

CWE-497.name: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
CWE-497.description: The product does not properly prevent sensitive system-level information from being accessed by unauthorized actors who do not have the same level of access to the underlying system as the product does.

CWE-501.name: Trust Boundary Violation
CWE-501.description: The product mixes trusted and untrusted data in the same data structure or structured message.

CWE-558.name: Use of getlogin() in Multithreaded Application
CWE-558.description: The product uses the getlogin() function in a multithreaded context, potentially causing it to return incorrect values.

CWE-785.name: Use of Path Manipulation Function without Maximum-sized Buffer
CWE-785.description: The product invokes a function for normalizing paths or file names, but it provides an output buffer that is smaller than the maximum possible size, such as PATH_MAX.

CWE-798.name: Use of Hard-coded Credentials
CWE-798.description: The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.
